awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of An Isothermal Titration Calorimeter for Studying Ligand-Macromolecule Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF) Programs.  Professor Liang Xue from the University of the Pacific and colleagues Andreas Franz, Jerry Tsai and Xiaoling Li have acquired an isothermal titration calorimeter (ITC). This technique is used to determine the thermodynamic parameters of interactions in solution. The instrument consists of two cells enclosed in an adiabatic jacket that does not allow transfer of heat between the system being studied and its surrounding, thus the name isothermal meaning same temperature. Thermodynamics is the branch of chemical physics concerned with heat and temperature and their relation to energy and work. The calorimeter is used to study the binding and interaction of a ligand with a substrate. In one experiment the ligand is a small organic molecule and the substrate is DNA. The thermodynamics of the interaction is measured. Such binding data may be useful in investigating possible medicinal targets. The various research projects are undertaken by undergraduate students as well as high school students during the summer. Students from Delta College, a community college, are also being trained to use this modern instrumentation useful in the chemical and biochemical fields. 

The instrument is used in research and education at all levels, particularly by undergraduate students. It is being used to understand G4 ligands binding to G-quadruplex DNA which are secondary structures formed in nucleic acids by sequences rich in guanine. The instrument is also employed to validate the knob-socket protein packing statistical model which considers how protuberances fit into voids.  The conformational changes of glycan and water liberation upon protein binding is being studied.  Data are obtained to understand the structures of small molecules that stabilize the transport protein transthyretin that serves as carrier of the thyroid hormone.  The instrument is also used in experiments designing peptides for targeting the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding interactions between biologically relevant molecules including drug-nucleic acid, drug-protein, protein-protein, and nucleic acid-protein is crucial for drug development and pharmaceutical applications. Although several biophysical tools are available, isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC) is a gold standard that allows one to numerically compare these interactions. It is the only label-free method to date that directly measures the heat associated with biological interactions in solution at the micromolar scales. Another microcalorimetry technique, differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), can directly measure the heat associated with biological transformations such as protein and nucleic acid folding and unfolding with minimal sample amounts.

This award funded the purchase of two shared microcalorimetry instruments (Combo offer), Affinity ITC and Nano DSC, manufactured by TA Instruments. Since the installations on December 4, 2018, both instruments have been extensively used for research and pedagogical activities by the groups of the PI, the Co-PIs, and two junior faculty members in the chemistry department. The major accomplished projects on ITC include finding novel G-quadruplex/triplex DNA specific binding molecules for cancer intervention, developing DNA-peptide inhibitors for ubiquitin pathways, finding better drugs for inhibition of microphase migration inhibitory factor-2, and establishing carbohydrate-enzyme interactions as models. The major accomplished projects on DSC include measuring nucleic acid stability for drug development and peptide inhibitor stability for better formulation. To date, one manuscript was published, and one manuscript was submitted (under review). Several other manuscripts are in various stages of preparation for publication. Six conference presentations with ITC data were presented by graduate and undergraduate research students. One dissertation and one thesis with ITC data have been completed. One dissertation with DSC data will be defended in December 2021.

This award allows us to provide training for users on these state-of-the-art instruments. Initial 2-day on-site training for eleven users was provided by a TA Instruments specialist. The training included basic ITC and DSC theories, plausible applications, and maintenance tips followed by hands-on training on titration of calcium with EDTA using ITC and investigation of protein stability using DSC. Subsequent training for new users was provided by the PI (Dr. Liang Xue) and his graduate students. Over the course of this award, a total of thirty users have received training to use ITC and/or DSC for their research projects. These individuals have included faculty, graduate students, and undergraduate research students. In addition, training of ITC was provided to one international exchange student and one under-represented high school summer research student from the American Chemical Society Project SEED (Summer Experiences for the Economically Disadvantaged) program.

This award also enables us to teach new bioanalytical technologies to undergraduate STEM students by providing hands-on and real-time experiences. The faculty members in the department have successfully implemented ITC experiments, data, and theories into the curriculum of two upper-division undergraduate chemistry courses (instrumental analysis and nucleic acid chemistry courses). The course contents of ITC include basic concepts, mechanics, data analysis using the free software provided by TA instruments, and derivatization of mathematical modes behind ITC data analysis.

Overall, within the grant period, both the ITC and DSC instruments have been successfully set up for creative research and pedagogical activities. Through the research and training projects, the microcalorimetric concepts have been introduced to a broader audience ranging from high school to graduate level. Both ITC and DSC will continue to be the key research and teaching instruments for the PI, Co-PIs, and other faculty as well as their group members for years to come.
